ETV has also opened new paths of professional
consciousness for teachers. “Conversation about
teaching techniques used to be almost taboo
among teachers,” Platt says. “If someone asked
about the way you brought across a certain point
in your class, it was a tacit admission of igno¬
rance. Now ETV has made teaching a team re¬
sponsibility, among the teacher on camera, his
counterparts in the classrooms, and their super¬
visors. ’ ’ ETV does not subordinate the role of the
classroom teacher; quite the opposite. Platt, who
returned to classroom teaching for two years and
then, in 1960, became a teacher in the Midwest
Program on Airborne Television, knows ETV
from both sides of the screen. ‘ ‘ I spent more time
preparing for the few minutes left to me as a
classroom teacher during a television class than
I would for the forty-five minutes of a non-tele¬
vision class. The better the television lesson, the
more the classroom teacher must be on his toes.
He spoon-feeds less. The televised portion of the
lesson forces him to stimulate student questions
and provoke reading and discussion. It is pegged
to a norm, and the classroom teacher is challenged
to identify and help students who are behind or
ahead of the norm. ETV lets you do this without
holding up the rest of the class.”
